body: Actually – there isn’t even an index for the foreign key between those two tables. I know mysql does it automatically and it’s needed (you can’t delete it), but Postgre doesn’t. Only on primary keys and unique constraints.
What is does is getting messages from `cs-CZ` and, if any messages is missing, getting it from `cs`. Your query produces different result since you're getting both if both exist.

Ok, so by the complicated query you’re trying to find at least “cs” language, if there isn’t any “cs-CZ”, before you end up with the last option – showing the source language. Right?

My problem was, I didn’t wonder about option, where there are two versions of the same language. There is nothing like that in my Czech language, so I didn’t see the need.

Which leads me to some thoughts –I’ve read on some places, I should use the long version of my language, so instead of “cs” use “cs-CZ” in app setting. So I did. In the config for console message I use “cs”, but in the end, it doesn’t matter. The query is still complicated even if it’s sett to “cs-CZ”. But if I change the app language from “cs-CZ” to “cs”, the Yii is clever enough and look at the beautiful query now (even if I'm still wondering why Yii uses the old way of joining table and not the "join style"):

``` sql
SELECT
    "t1"."message" AS "message",
    "t2"."translation" AS "translation"
FROM
    "sp_source_message" "t1",
    "sp_message" "t2"
WHERE
    ("t1"."id" = "t2"."id")
AND ("t1"."category" = 'app')
AND ("t2"."language" = 'cs')
```

Well my question is – what’s the benefit of using “cs-CZ” if there isn’t any other version of “cs” language? Now it seems to be more reasonable to use only the “cs”.

But still – back to the overcomplicated query. I still thing it isn’t written good in performance wise, because the last subquery is executed for every row and it still selects the same. From my knowledge, subqueries are essential where you need to use some var from the query itself, like ID of the row or something. This isn’t the case. So in some terrible scenarios you can generate hundreds of not necessary subqueries.

I can see two solutions:
1. Do the first select first, store the ids into variable and then use it for excluding in the second part.
2. Use groupby and order like this 

``` sql
… where "t2"."language" = 'cs-CZ' OR "t2"."language" = 'cs' group by (columns without t2.language) order by t2.language
```

Then due the group by you always get only one row per language, and the “cs” (shorter) will have bigger priority due the order statemen.

The question is. What’s more efficient. I believe the first one.

And the last thing – there is still open question about the indexes. What do you think about it?

And there is still one another improvement, which crossed my mind. If I use more categories, sometimes more than one are used on the page. Is it even possible to first collect some info, which categories are gonna be used and then select them in one query?

> Ok, so by the complicated query you’re trying to find at least “cs” language, if there isn’t any “cs-CZ”, before you end up with the last option – showing the source language. Right?

Yes.

> even if I'm still wondering why Yii uses the old way of joining table and not the "join style"

That could be changed. Not critical though.

> Well my question is – what’s the benefit of using “cs-CZ” if there isn’t any other version of “cs” language? Now it seems to be more reasonable to use only the “cs”.

If you're translating only then none. CZ gives some hints to intl ICU about how to format currencies, dates etc. according to the country standards.

> I can see two solutions

If you can get EXPLAIN for both and probably measure performance difference for all three, that would be excellent.

> And the last thing – there is still open question about the indexes. What do you think about it?

If EXPLAIN will get better because of indexes, I'm open to adding these.

> And there is still one another improvement, which crossed my mind. If I use more categories, sometimes more than one are used on the page. Is it even possible to first collect some info, which categories are gonna be used and then select them in one query?

Yes, sounds like a good idea.

Ok. I did my homework. Here are some specs:

| Q | A |
| --- | --- |
| DB engine | Postgre 9.4.5. |
| Yii version | 2.0.8 |
| System | Win 10 |
| Hardware | Local PC with SSD disc; QuadCore 4,3Ghz; 16GB RAM |

Test sourceMessage table has 19100 entries. 5 different categories – 10 000, 5 000, 3 000, 1 000, 100. Table messages has 5 languages, which is almost 100k entries in total. 

This of course isn’t real life example. But it can help see the results more clearly. On the other hand, the speed on busy or shared server without SSD could be also rapidly slower.
Every single query was executed right after PostgreSQL restart. So no internal cache was applied (tested). 5 runs for every query combination to see the range.

**Queries:**
- Query 1: the original one – see above
- Query 2: Splits the two selects. From first, takes the id, which uses in the second instead of the subquery – see above.
- Query2: Using the group by with orderby – see above.

Queries with EXPLAIN ANALYZE results: [yii2-messages-queries.zip](https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/files/316427/yii2-messages-queries.zip)

Here are some results. I’ve compared all 3 queries on indexed and non-indexed tables. I’ve also done variations for the biggest category and smallest, because there are some big differences. Not only the amount of data varies, but even the internal optimizer of PostgreSQL changes the complexity of internal query as you can see in EXPLAIN. But it can vary a lot depending on db engine.

**Tables without Index:** 
- **Query 1**
  - Smallest category: 33 – 37 ms
  - Biggest category: 58 – 72 ms
- **Query 2**
  - Smallest category: 
    1. 7 - 11 ms
    2.  9 – 11 ms
  - Biggest category:
    1.  20 – 26 ms
    2.  40 – 44 ms
- **Query 3**
  *Smallest category: 9-21ms
  - Biggest category: 89 - 90 (ups :) )
  - Biggest category light (without GROUP BY and ORDER – we can easily manage it in PHP): 44 – 45 ms.

**Tables with index** (message.language, source_message.category):
- **Query 1**
  - Smallest category: 5 – 6 ms
  - Biggest category: 36 – 38 ms
- **Query 2**
  - Smallest category: 
    1.  5 - 10 ms
    2.  6 – 9 ms
  - Biggest category:
    1.  5 – 11 ms
    2.  37 – 42 ms
- **Query 3**
  - Smallest category: 5-7ms
  - Biggest category: 78 – 85 (ups again :) )
  - Biggest category light (without GROUP BY and ORDER – we can easily manage it in PHP): 35 – 41 ms.

**My conclusions?**
- The real life impact with any of these queries will be probably small. With cache turned on I’d easily turn my sight away.
- There really are some positive differences in my optimized queries, but also some drawbacks, depending on the size of category
- Buuuut everything fades out, when indexes come on stage.

**My suggestion?**

Let’s just apply the two indexes. It has only positives, no drawbacks.
What do you think about that?
I'm all for it. Do you want to make a pull request?

Well I haven’t dig into migrations to much yet, but I guess add two indexes won’t be such a big deal. Ok then. I’ll take it in few days (won’t be here now).
What about the enhancement where Yii recognize what categories are gonna be used and only after that selects everything in one query. Do you think it’s worth it?
It complicates things a bit while not giving us much improvement (or am I wrong?) so I think while indexes are certainly an improvement, this change is questionable.

issue.title: Adds indexes on message tables which partly fixes #11725

labels.name: status:under development
labels.description: Someone is working on a pull request.

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
| Q | A |
| --- | --- |
| Is bugfix? | no |
| New feature? | enhancement |
| Breaks BC? | no |
| Tests pass? | - |
| Fixed issues | #11725 |

I added message indexes into the migration script and tested it.

I also added indexes into the SQL file for PostgreSQL. I used “clustered” (see https://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.1/static/sql-cluster.html), which isn’t possible via migration method, but it’s welcome here. Also tested.

I’m afraid I don’t have enough knowledge to complete other languages. Is it generated or made manually? Do you think you could complete it?

DBs support:
- [x] PostgreSQL
- [x] MySQL
- [x] MSSQL
- [x] SQLite
- [x] Oracle

body:
Well there is my small try to do my first proper PR via this workflow - https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blob/master/docs/internals/git-workflow.md. Hope it helps a bit, because it’s not complete. There are some special SQL files for other SQL languages which I don’t know.

> It complicates things a bit while not giving us much improvement (or am I wrong?) so I think while indexes are certainly an improvement, this change is questionable.

I have no idea how complicated it could be, but if it’s more than “a bit”, you’re probably right - indexes and caching should be ok here. But in principle, in large projects with lots of categories, where this issue cumulates, it could help. So if there is some box for issue with low priority, you know, the one which nobody visits, we could put it there.
I think we'll finish indexes pull request for other DBs, merge it and close the issue till another request for performance improvement pops up.
Ok. What about the other databases? I could check their docs and make something, but can’t truly test it. I know it’s just index but still.

I used some already crated queries in Yii and some docs and added other SQL languages. Hope it's correct, but again - someone with the db installed should test it.

Is there a need to do another PR or commit after PR is legit approach?
